text.headline: Microsoft Founded
text.text: Bill Gates and Paul Allen establish Microsoft in Albuquerque, New Mexico, marking the beginning of a software giant.

media.caption: Bill Gates and Paul Allen in the early days of Microsoft.

text.headline: Microsoft Partners with IBM
text.text: Microsoft collaborates with IBM to develop MS-DOS, a pivotal operating system for IBM PCs.

media.caption: IBM's first personal computer running MS-DOS.

text.headline: Windows 1.0 Released
text.text: Microsoft's first step away from the command line. It introduced the mouse, 'windows' that couldn't overlap (they tiled), and the first apps like Paint and Notepad.

text.headline: Windows 3.1 Released
text.text: The release that made Windows a household name. It sold 3 million copies in two months and introduced the iconic Minesweeper and Solitaire games.

text.headline: Windows 95: The World Starts Up
text.text: Accompanied by a massive marketing campaign featuring the Rolling Stones, Windows 95 introduced the 'Start' button, the Taskbar, and long filenames. It bridged the gap between the 16-bit and 32-bit eras, forever changing how humans interact with PCs.

media.caption: The midnight launch of Windows 95 saw lines around the block and a very excited public!

text.headline: Windows 98: Tuned for the Web
text.text: Described as 'Works Better, Plays Better,' Windows 98 was the first version designed specifically for the internet age. It introduced the 'Back' and 'Forward' navigation buttons in Explorer and significantly improved USB support, making 'Plug and Play' a reality.

media.caption: Windows 98 integrated the browser directly into the desktop experience.

text.headline: Windows XP Released
text.text: The 'Gold Standard' for a decade. It united the crash-prone consumer 9x series with the stable NT engine, surviving long past its intended retirement.

media.caption: The iconic 'Bliss' wallpaper of Windows XP.

text.headline: Windows Vista Released
text.text: Featuring the Aero graphical interface, Windows Vista emphasizes security with User Account Control. The focus on security made for a rocky user experience, but this OS actually introduced many much-needed upgrades.

text.headline: Windows 7: Refined and Reliable
text.text: After the struggles of Vista, Windows 7 arrived as a streamlined, faster, and more stable successor. It introduced the 'Pin' feature to the taskbar and 'Snap' for window management, becoming so beloved that many users refused to upgrade for over a decade.

media.caption: Windows 7 combined the beauty of Aero with the speed users craved.

text.headline: Windows 8: The Tablet Gamble
text.text: In a bold move to compete with tablets, Microsoft removed the Start Menu in favor of a full-screen 'Start Screen' with Live Tiles. The 'Metro' UI was designed for touchscreens, but the radical change alienated traditional desktop users and led to the quick release of Windows 8.1.

media.caption: The controversial 'Live Tile' interface of Windows 8.

text.headline: Windows 10 Released
text.text: Microsoft introduces Windows 10 with the return of the Start Menu, Cortana, and Microsoft Edge. Positioned as 'the last version of Windows,' it aimed to fix the touch-heavy focus of Windows 8 by bringing back the Start menu and introducing a unified OS across devices.

media.caption: Ten days before the release of Windows 10, the marketing campaign was already underway.

text.headline: Windows 11 Released
text.text: Windows 11 introduces a modern UI, centered Start Menu, and enhanced gaming features.

text.headline: Windows Server 2022 Released
text.text: Windows Server 2022 enhances security, hybrid cloud support, and performance improvements.

media.caption: Windows Server 2022 featured a datacenter edition
